{{Infobox organization |name = National Music Publishers' Association |image = National Music Publishers Association logo.png |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |motto = |formation = {{Start date and age|1917}} |extinction = |type = [[Trade association]] |headquarters = |location = [[United States]] |membership = |language = |leader_title = President and CEO |leader_name = [[David Israelite]]{{cite news|last=Plambeck|first=Joseph|title=Internet File-Sharing Service Is Sued by Music Publishers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/17/business/media/17lime.html|accessdate=December 12, 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=June 16, 2010}} |leader_title2= Board of Directors |leader_name2 = Martin Bandier
Caroline Bienstock
Jody Gerson
Lee Eastman
Willard Ahdritz
Barry Coburn
Neil Gillis
Zach Katz
Chip McLean
Justin Kalifowitz
Leeds Levy
David Renzer
[[Ralph Peer, II]]
Matt Pincus
Irwin Z. Robinson
Jody Klein
Cameron Strang
Golnar Khosrowshahi |key_people = |num_staff = |budget = |website = [http://nmpa.org nmpa.org] }} The '''National Music Publishers' Association''' (NMPA) is a [[trade association]] for the American [[Music publisher (popular music)|music publishing industry]]. Founded in 1917, the NMPA aims to "protect its members' [[intellectual property|property]] [[copyright|rights]] on the legislative, litigation, and regulatory fronts."{{cite web|title=NMPA Mission Statement|url=http://nmpa.org/aboutnmpa/mission.asp|publisher=National Music Publishers Association|accessdate=December 12, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091030222832/http://www.nmpa.org/aboutnmpa/mission.asp|archivedate=October 30, 2009|df=}} The NMPA has pursued litigation against numerous organizations, including [[Amway]],[http://www.culteducation.com/reference/amway/amway4.html Amway: The Untold Story: NMPA] (Press release), 25 November 2006. [[YouTube]], [[Kazaa]], [[LimeWire]], [[Fullscreen (company)|FullScreen]]{{Cite web|title = National Music Publishers Association Files Copyright Infringement Suit Against Fullscreen|url = http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/legal-and-management/5638264/national-music-publishers-association-files-copyright|website = Billboard|accessdate = 2015-11-25}} and [[Napster]]. ==History== === First half of the 20th century === The NMPA was founded in 1917 as the Music Publishers' Protective Association, seeking to end the practice of publishers having to pay [[vaudeville]] theaters for performing their music. The [[payola]] was said to have reached $400,000. The MPPA mandate went into effect May 7, 1917. Founding firms included: * Broadway Music Corporation * Joseph W. Stern & Co. * [[Waterson, Berlin & Snyder, Inc.]] * [[Al Piantadosi|Al Piantadosi & Co.]] * [[Leo Feist|Leo Feist Co.]] * [[T. B. Harms & Francis, Day & Hunter, Inc.]] * Maurice Richmond (1880–1965) * Jos. Morris Co. * [[Charles K. Harris]] * [[Harry Von Tilzer|Harry Von Tilzer Co.]] * [[Harry Von Tilzer|Shapiro, Bernstein & Co.]] * [[Harry Von Tilzer|M. Witmark & Sons]] * [[Harry Von Tilzer|James Kendis (1883–1946)]] * [[Harry Von Tilzer|James Brockman]] * [[Harry Von Tilzer|Kalmar, Puck & Abrahams Consolidated, Inc. (]][[Bert Kalmar]], Harry Puck, [[Maurice Abrahams|Maurice W. Abrahams]]) * [[Harry Von Tilzer|F.J.A. Forster Co.]] * [[Harry Von Tilzer|McCarthy & Fisher]] * [[Harry Von Tilzer|A. J. Stasny Music Co.]] * [[Harry Von Tilzer|J.H. Remick & Co.]] * [[Harry Von Tilzer|Church, Paxson & Co.]] * [[Harry Von Tilzer|Karczag Publishing Company (Wilhelm Karczag; 1859–1923)]] * [[Harry Von Tilzer|William Jerome]] In 1927, the NMPA founded the [[Harry Fox Agency]], a [[mechanical license|mechanical rights]] collecting society.{{cite web|title=About HFA|url=http://www.harryfox.com/public/AboutHFA.jsp|publisher=Harry Fox Agency|accessdate=December 12, 2011}} === Second half of the 20th century === In 1966 the name of the Music Publishers' Protective Association was changed to the National Music Publishers Association. The NMPA lobbies federal legislators and regulators on behalf of music publishers and crafted guidelines for the [[Copyright Act of 1976]].{{cite book|last=Frankel|first=James|title=The Teacher's Guide to Music, Media, and Copyright Law|year=2009|publisher=Hal Leonard|location=New York|isbn=978-1-4234-4344-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MH0OILv1B18C&pg=PA82|page=82}} === 21st century === In September 2001, the NMPA reached a settlement with [[Napster]], turning the company into a fee-based service with publishers licensing music to the users.[http://www.moyak.com/papers/napster-history.html "Early History of Napster"], by Moya K. Mason, 2010 The NMPA won a judgment against [[peer-to-peer]] filing service [[StreamCast Networks]] in September 2006.{{cite news|last=Jones|first=K. C.|title=Music Publishers Sue YouTube|url=http://www.informationweek.com/news/201300611|accessdate=December 12, 2011|newspaper=InformationWeek|date=August 7, 2007}} In 2007, NMPA joined a lawsuit against [[YouTube]] for hosting user-generated videos containing music under copyright. The suit was dropped four years later.{{cite news|title=Music Publishers to Join YouTube Suit|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/07/technology/07youtube.html|accessdate=December 12, 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 7, 2007|agency=Associated Press}}{{cite news|last=Lang|first=Brent|title=Music Publishers Drop Copyright Suit Against YouTube|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/17/idUS115394738920110817|accessdate=December 12, 2011|newspaper=TheWrap|date=August 17, 2011}} Along with the [[Music Publishers' Association]] (MPA), the NMPA has been responsible for taking many free guitar [[tablature]] web sites offline. NMPA President David Israelite asserted that "[u]nauthorised use of lyrics and tablature deprives the songwriter of the ability to make a living, and is no different than stealing".{{cite news|last=Youngs|first=Ian|title=Song sites face legal crackdown|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/4508158.stm|accessdate=December 12, 2011|newspaper=BBC News|date=December 12, 2005}} The NMPA also pushed for rate hikes for legal downloads of music in 2008.{{cite news|last=Albanesius|first=Chloe|title=Music-Download Royalty Rates Left Unchanged|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2331598,00.asp|accessdate=December 12, 2011|newspaper=PC Magazine|date=October 2, 2008}} In 2010, the NMPA represented [[EMI]], [[Sony/ATV Music Publishing|Sony/ATV]], [[Universal Music Publishing Group|Universal]] and [[Warner/Chappell Music|Warner/Chappell]], Bug, [[MPL Communications]], [[Peermusic]] and the Richmond Organization in a lawsuit against [[LimeWire]]. The suit sought $150,000 for each song that was distributed.{{cite news|last=Mick|first=Jason|title=New Suit Against Limewire Could Total 15 Times Music Industry's Yearly Income|url=http://www.dailytech.com/New+Suit+Against+Limewire+Could+Total+15+Times+Music+Industrys+Yearly+Income/article18769.htm|accessdate=December 12, 2011|newspaper=Daily Tech|date=June 18, 2010}} NMPA is a member of the [[International Intellectual Property Alliance]], a business alliance which amongst others publishes the [[Special 301 Report]], a controversial list of countries that the coalition of [[copyright]] holders feel do not do enough to combat [[copyright infringement]]s.{{cite news|last=Masnick|first=Mike|title=IIPA's Section 301 Filing Shows It's Really Not At All Interested In Reducing Copyright Infringement|url=http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20100224/0229248284.shtml|accessdate=December 12, 2011|newspaper=Tech Dirt|date=February 24, 2010}} In 2015, the NMPA sold the Harry Fox Agency to [[SESAC]].{{Cite web|title = SESAC Finalizes Acquisition of Harry Fox Agency|url = http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6693385/sesac-finalizes-acquisition-of-harry-fox-agency|website = Billboard|accessdate = 2015-11-25}} In December 2016, the NMPA announced that it had reached an agreement to with YouTube to allow the distribution of royalties for musical works used in videos on YouTube where ownership was previously unknown.Chris Cooke, [http://www.completemusicupdate.com/article/nmpa-announces-deal-with-youtube-over-unpaid-song-royalties/ "NMPA announces deal with YouTube over unpaid song royalties,"] ''Completemusicupdate.com'', December 9, 2016 ==See also== * ''[[Warner/Chappell Music Inc. v. Fullscreen Inc.]]'' *[[Motion Picture Association of America]] *[[Recording Industry Association of America]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= [https://books.google.com/books?id=7goEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA3 "BMI Counsel Deals With 'Puff' Tales"]''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', April 21, 1958, pg. 3 [https://archive.org/stream/variety46-1917-05#page/n3/mode/2up/search/%22payments+end%22 "Song Payments End This Week,"] ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', May 4, 1917, pg. 3 }} ==External links== * {{official website}} *[https://www.namm.org/library/oral-history/david-israelite David Israelite Interview - NAMM Oral History Library (2013)] [[Category:1917 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1917]] [[Category:Copyright collection societies]] [[Category:Music organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Music industry associations]] [[Category:Music publishing companies of the United States]]

[[File:Burghley nef.jpg|thumb|The [[Burghley Nef]], [[silver-gilt]] (with sections ungilded), and [[nautilus shell]], 1527–28, France, [[V&A Museum]]]] [[File:Les Très Riches Heures du duc de Berry Janvier.jpg|thumb|Calendar miniature for January from the ''[[Très Riches Heures du Duc de Berry]]'']] A '''nef''' is an extravagant table ornament and container used in the [[Middle Ages]] and [[Renaissance]], made of [[precious metal]]s in the shape of a ship – ''nef'' was another word for a [[carrack]] in French. If not just used for decoration, it could hold [[salt]] or [[spice]]s (the latter being very expensive in the Middle Ages), or [[cutlery]], or even [[napkin]]s. The large nef depicted in the well-known calendar miniature for January from the ''[[Très Riches Heures du Duc de Berry]]'' is being used to hold, and perhaps wash, gilt dishes from the table service.<ref>Campbell 2006, p. 412.</ref> Nefs are recorded in France as early as 1239,<ref>Lightbown 1978, p. 3.</ref> initially consisting of just the [[hull (watercraft)|hull]], and perhaps initially used to drink from; by the 14th century the most elaborate had masts, sails and even crew, and had become too crowded with such details to be used as containers for anything. The so-called [[Mechanical Galleon]] in the [[British Museum]] is a late 16th-century German nef which was also a clock and [[automaton]], with moving figures and music.
A nef was usually made of [[silver]], [[silver-gilt]] or [[gold]], often further embellished with [[Vitreous enamel|enamel]] and [[Gemstone|jewel]]s. A [[nautilus shell]] often formed the hull of the ship, as in the [[Burghley Nef]] (illustrated). Some nefs had wheels to allow them to be rolled from one end of the table to the other, but most had legs or pedestals. The nef was placed in front of the most important person at table as a mark of their status.
The equivalent in religious plate is a ''navicula'', Latin for small ship, and also a term in English for a boat-shaped [[incense]]-holder.<ref>[[OED]], "Navicula. 3"</ref>
== See also == * [[Schlüsselfelder Ship]]
== Notes == {{reflist|3}}
== References == *{{cite book|editor-last=Campbell |editor-first=Gordon|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R8BMW6Au7pQC&pg=PA412&dq=Nef+pepper+silver&hl=en&ei=rLwBTKkTmqadA6_NhLkM&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Nef%20pepper%20silver&f=false |title=The Grove Encyclopedia of Decorative Arts, Volume 1|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2006|isbn=0-19-518948-5}} *{{cite book |last=Lightbown |first=R. W.|title=Secular Goldsmith's Work in Medieval France: A History|location=London |publisher=Society of Antiquaries of London |year=1978|isbn=0500990271}} *{{cite book |last=Steele |first=Philip |title=Castles |year=1995 |publisher=Kingfisher |location=New York |isbn=1-85697-547-9 |page=36}}
== Further reading == *Oman, Charles (1963). ''Medieval Silver Nefs.'' London: Her Majesty's Stationery Office. *Truman, Charles (1989). "Ships on Board". ''[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]]'', vol. 183, no. 38: 218-221.
== External links == {{Commons category|Nefs (metalwork)}} *[http://www.larsdatter.com/nefs.htm Nefs in the Middle Ages and Renaissance] Links to nefs in museums, as well as medieval illustrations of nefs, demonstrating the range of uses for pre-17th century nefs.
[[Category:Serving and dining]] [[Category:Silver objects]] [[Category:Silver-gilt objects]] [[Category:Marine art]] [[Category:Medieval European metalwork objects]]

revision.text:
{{Intellectual property}} '''Paracopyright''' ("pseudocopyright" or "metacopyright") is legal protection above and beyond traditional [[copyright]]. The most often cited example is "legal protection for technical measures" from the 1996 [[World Intellectual Property Organization|WIPO]] Internet treaties. Paracopyright provisions in these treaties are not about the term or scope of copyright, but instead are about providing legal protections for the technologies that may be used by copyright holders.
Paracopyrights afford legal protection to technologies that claim to be used to protect copyrights, but that are ineffective in that goal. A technical measure can not stop a technically sophisticated person who wishes to infringe copyright. To use the "digital locks" analogy, there is no need to "pick the lock" as the keys necessary to decode the content are embedded within authorized access technology. Both the locked content and the technology containing the key are commercially available to an infringer. Once a single person decodes a technical measure, the decoded content can be made available to others in the same way as if the technical measure never existed.
The effect of these technical measures are to impose specific contractual [[license agreement]]s on those conforming to copyright law. As a concept, therefore, paracopyrights are perhaps better understood as a part of [[contract law]] and not copyright law. Unfortunately, important regulations regarding consumer protection and the "freedom to contract" are not imported directly into paracopyright laws, potentially creating imbalances in the law and harmful [[unintended consequence]]s.
Copyright is traditionally understood as a statutorily defined [[Bundle of rights|bundle of exclusive rights]] provided to copyright holders. An [[Copyright infringement|infringement of copyright]] takes place when someone exercises one or more of the copyright holder’s exclusive rights without his or her permission. Anti-circumvention and anti-device provisions do not fit under this paradigm of a bundle of exclusive rights. On one hand, a copyright owner has the exclusive right to copy his or her work, and that exclusive right is infringed when someone else copies the work without permission. It is quite another story, however, to think about copyright holders having the exclusive right to circumvent TPMs ([[Technical Protection Measure]]) that they apply to their works, and the exclusive right to make and distribute devices that enable or facilitate circumvention of TPMs. Even assuming that this problem could be overcome, attempting to force anti-circumvention and anti-device provisions to fit the mold of the [[bundle of rights]] paradigm seems to necessitate adding a number of related rights to the bundle, including the exclusive right to apply a TPM to a copyright work.
